intro: Quercus ochracea, commonly known as the yellow oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. The tree is characterized by its oval-shaped leaves that turn yellow in the fall and its acorns, which are enclosed in a cupule. Quercus ochracea typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and can reach heights of up to 30 meters. It plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
